data.title: Try a different approach for preventing autoscroll to off-screen input
data.body:
This fixes a bug that got introduced in #13880 which was causing lines to disappear due to the browser trying to scroll the hidden input into view after it was focused.

![image_1024](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/26637604/2ccb612a-4620-11e7-8032-625b15c31911.png)

With this pull-request we unconditionally restore the scroll top and the scroll left properties of the scroll view to 0 every time the hidden input is focused.

/cc: @atom/maintainers

data.title: Some command line options (--enable-gpu-rasterization) require a different order than specified in --help
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * [X] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * [X] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * [X] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * [X] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * [X] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When starting atom from the command line, it seems some options have to be specified after the file path. This is not documented AFAICT.

Specifically I found that `--enable-gpu-rasterization` cannot come before the file path (as specified in `--help` usage, it only works correctly when it comes after).

I found this when reading and attempting workarounds for: 
https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/12634

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Make sure you close all atom windows and quit atom completely.
2. Start atom from the command line:
```
atom --enable-gpu-rasterization ~/some_project
```

**Expected behavior:** Atom starts, and opens the folder `~/some_project`

**Actual behavior:** Atom opens, but doesn't open the project folder

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

**Note:** Seems to be the same for `--disable-gpu` as well.

### Workaround
Switch the order of the arguments:
```
atom ~/some_project --enable-gpu-rasterization
```
or use a function (add to `~/.bash_profile`:
```
function atom-gpu {
    atom $1 --enable-gpu-rasterization ;
}
```

### Versions

Atom    : 1.17.2
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

Mac OS Sierra
Version 10.12.5

### Additional Information

This might be intended behaviour, for the more advanced options parameters, but I believe it should be documented (better?).

I'm sorry if this is documented somewhere, I tried searching Issues, FAQ, and message board, but couldn't find anything. Feel free to link to relevant docs and close issue if appropriate.

data.title: git ignore rules in .gitignore files that are in a parent directory of an Atom project are not used in search results
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

For a project with the following directory structure:

    ./.git
    ./.gitignore
    ./hello.tmp
    ./hello.txt
    ./subproject
    ./subproject/index.html
    ./subproject/index.tmp

With the following .gitignore:

    *.tmp

If you open the root project, the search (cmd+shift+p) does not show the .tmp files and the file tree view on the side shows them greyed out, which is exactly what should happen.

If you however want to only work on `subproject/`, the .tmp files are greyed out in the side pane but they do show up in the search results. I think they shouldn't show up in the search results.

A workaround is to simply copy the `.gitignore` contents of the parent directory into the `subproject` directory, but I think this is an Atom bug that should be addressed.

Screenshots to make everything clearer:

Root project, everything is good:

![parent-project-search](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/787566/26588842/5f61bb0c-454e-11e7-8ead-da00e2f4e836.png)
![parent-project](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/787566/26588844/5f656bee-454e-11e7-9c78-098e62cf4795.png)

Subproject, the search shows results that should be omitted:

![subproject](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/787566/26588841/5f423156-454e-11e7-88eb-c5520165624c.png)
![subproject-search](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/787566/26588843/5f659164-454e-11e7-8f4a-a4f68b2eb1eb.png)




### Steps to Reproduce

1. Setup a git repository with a `.gitignore` like described above. [I made one here](https://github.com/vladvelici/atom-gitignore-bug-report-sample-repo)
2. Open the project, observe the tree file navigation sidebar and the search for the git ignored files.
3. Open a subfolder, observe the tree file navigation correctly greying out git ignored files but the search is not omitting those files.

**Expected behavior:** The search should omit the git ignored files even if the .gitignore file is in a parent directory outside the Atom project.

**Actual behavior:** The search does not omit those files, but the file navigator does grey them out.

**Reproduces how often:** It always behaves the same.

### Versions

Vlads-MacBook-Air:test vlad$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.17.2
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
Vlads-MacBook-Air:test vlad$ apm --version
apm  1.17.0
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.11.0

Running macOS 10.12.5.

### Description

data.title: Fix pane resizing issue
data.body:
Check if there is more than one pane in the pane-container before resizing the pane

### Requirements

* Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion.
* All new code requires tests to ensure against regressions

### Description of the Change

When a request to resize a pane is sent, atom never checked how many panes were present in the pane-container. This resulted in a situation where if a package or the user tried to resize the pane, and there was only one pane, the pane would resize itself though there was no other pane to take up the space it freed.

The PR adds a check to the pane model, to check the number of panes in its container, before resizing the pane. If there is only one pane in the pane's container, it does not try to resize the pane, otherwise, resize as before.

### Alternate Designs

NA

### Why Should This Be In Core?

Fixes incorrect behaviour when resizing panes.

### Benefits

Fixes issue #11673 

### Possible Drawbacks

None that I can think of

### Applicable Issues

#11673

data.title: Proposal: Allow pane items to be marked as "cannot cause activation"
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Currently with Atom's new dock feature (Atom 1.17.0+) there is an issue with many packages using the `atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor()` to get the currently active "editable" pane item. The problem is when docks were introduced many core features (such as the tree-view) were put into panes. Because of this the packages/items (like the tree-view) are marking their containing pane as active which causes certain pieces of functionality to not work as expected. As an example of this there was: [find-and-replace issue #901](https://github.com/atom/find-and-replace/issues/901) which was solved by forcing the find-and-replace package to always use the center pane (`atom.workspace.getCenter().getActiveTextEditor()`).

My proposed solution is to update the way that panes are activated. Currently when an item is activated inside of a pane it displays that item in the editor in it's corresponding pane. This does a few things:
  1. Focuses the activated item in it's pane (Potentially changing tabs)
  2. Shows the dock that the pane is contained in (if applicable)
  3. Marks the pane as active

Currently when you create/show a pane item you only have the option of either doing all 3 of these things or none of these things. I propose that we add another option which would be to allow a "soft-activate" which essentially does all of these things but the "final" step. The decision for whether or not a pane item is activated or "soft-activated" would potentially rely on a new config that can be passed when the pane item is created to mark it's "type." This would allow for both displaying items properly but not causing them to be considered when the `atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor()` method is triggered. This prevents items like the tree-view from being "activated" while also allowing them to be properly displayed.

Because of the scope of this change it would likely need to be done in a few stages.  The stages that seemed to work best in my overview were these;
  0. Change activation to be item based rather than pane based. But keeping the item's pane as what is returned in api functions (I.E. `atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor()`) as it does currently.
  1. Implement the api change (defaulting to normal activation functionality)
  2. Update the atom-flight-manual to document this new api change.
  3. Start with editing the tree-view to work with this new feature.
  4. Slowly convert other necessary core-packages to use this feature.

This should allow a fairly smooth transition and keep docks, panes, and Atom working as expected.

Potential issues:
  1. Making sure pane items cannot be "activated" regardless of pane.
  2. Being able to properly differentiate and document the differences between (activated, soft-activated, and not-activated)
  3. Validating that this change does not cause any unexpected functionality when relating to the focusing of different areas of the view.

The main purpose of this proposal was to get feedback, I was planning to implement this I just wanted to see if there were any thoughts, issues, or possible improvements.
